children.name: ChromeApi
children.comment: A common super class for the Chrome APIs.

children.name: available
children.comment:
Returns true if the API is available. The common causes of an API not being
avilable are:

 * a permission is missing in the application's manifest.json file
 * the API is defined on a newer version of Chrome then the current runtime

children.name: ChromeObject
children.comment: The abstract superclass of objects that can hold [JsObject] proxies.

Create a new instance of a `ChromeObject`, which creates and delegates to
a JsObject proxy.

children.name: fromProxy
children.comment:
Create a new instance of a `ChromeObject`, which delegates to the given
JsObject proxy.

dependencies.name: dart:core
dependencies.comment:
Built-in types, collections,
and other core functionality for every Dart program.

This library is automatically imported.

Some classes in this library,
such as [String] and [num],
support Dart's built-in data types.
Other classes, such as [List] and [Map], provide data structures
for managing collections of objects.
And still other classes represent commonly used types of data
such as URIs, dates and times, and errors.

## Numbers and booleans

[int] and [double] provide support for Dart's built-in numerical data types:
integers and double-precision floating point numbers, respectively.
An object of type [bool] is either true or false.
Variables of these types can be constructed from literals:

    int meaningOfLife = 42;
    double valueOfPi  = 3.141592;
    bool visible      = true;

## Strings and regular expressions

A [String] is immutable and represents a sequence of characters.

    String shakespeareQuote = "All the world's a stage, ...";

[StringBuffer] provides a way to construct strings efficiently.

    StringBuffer moreShakespeare = new StringBuffer();
    moreShakespeare.write('And all the men and women ');
    moreShakespeare.write('merely players; ...');

The String and StringBuffer classes implement string concatenation,
interpolation, and other string manipulation features.

    String philosophy = 'Live on ';
    String get palindrome => philosophy + philosophy.split('').reversed.join();

[RegExp] implements Dart regular expressions,
which provide a grammar for matching patterns within text.
For example, here's a regular expression that matches
a string of one or more digits:

    var numbers = new RegExp(r'\d+');

Dart regular expressions have the same syntax and semantics as
JavaScript regular expressions. See
<http://ecma-international.org/ecma-262/5.1/#sec-15.10>
for the specification of JavaScript regular expressions.

## Collections

The dart:core library provides basic collections,
such as [List], [Map], and [Set].

A List is an ordered collection of objects, with a length.
Lists are sometimes called arrays.
Use a List when you need to access objects by index.

    List superheroes = [ 'Batman', 'Superman', 'Harry Potter' ];

A Set is an unordered collection of unique objects.
You cannot get an item by index (position).
Adding a duplicate item has no effect.

    Set villains = new Set();
    villains.add('Joker');
    villains.addAll( ['Lex Luther', 'Voldemort'] );

A Map is an unordered collection of key-value pairs.
Maps are sometimes called associative arrays because
maps associate a key to some value for easy retrieval.
Keys are unique.
Use a Map when you need to access objects
by a unique identifier.

    Map sidekicks = { 'Batman': 'Robin',
                      'Superman': 'Lois Lane',
                      'Harry Potter': 'Ron and Hermione' };

In addition to these classes,
dart:core contains [Iterable],
an interface that defines functionality
common in collections of objects.
Examples include the ability
to run a function on each element in the collection,
to apply a test to each element,
to retrieve an object, and to determine length.

Iterable is implemented by List and Set,
and used by Map for its keys and values.

For other kinds of collections, check out the
[dart:collection](#dart-collection) library.

## Date and time

Use [DateTime] to represent a point in time
and [Duration] to represent a span of time.

You can create DateTime objects with constructors
or by parsing a correctly formatted string.

    DateTime now = new DateTime.now();
    DateTime berlinWallFell = new DateTime(1989, 11, 9);
    DateTime moonLanding = DateTime.parse("1969-07-20");

Create a Duration object specifying the individual time units.

    Duration timeRemaining = new Duration(hours:56, minutes:14);

In addition to DateTime and Duration,
dart:core contains the [Stopwatch] class for measuring elapsed time.

## Uri

A [Uri] object represents a uniform resource identifier,
which identifies a resource on the web.

    Uri dartlang = Uri.parse('http://dartlang.org/');

## Errors

The [Error] class represents the occurrence of an error
during runtime.
Subclasses of this class represent specific kinds of errors.

## Other documentation

For more information about how to use the built-in types, refer to
[Built-in Types](http://www.dartlang.org/docs/dart-up-and-running/contents/ch02.html#built-in-types)
in Chapter 2 of
[Dart: Up and Running](http://www.dartlang.org/docs/dart-up-and-running/).

Also, see
[dart:core - Numbers, Collections, Strings, and More](http://www.dartlang.org/docs/dart-up-and-running/contents/ch03.html#ch03-dartcore---strings-collections-and-more)
for more coverage of classes in this package.

The
[Dart Language Specification](http://www.dartlang.org/docs/spec/)
provides technical details.

children.name: Object
children.comment:
The base class for all Dart objects.

Because Object is the root of the Dart class hierarchy,
every other Dart class is a subclass of Object.

When you define a class, you should override [toString]
to return a string describing an instance of that class.
You might also need to define [hashCode] and [==], as described in the
[Implementing map keys]
(http://www.dartlang.org/docs/dart-up-and-running/contents/ch03.html#ch03-implementing-map-keys)
section of the [library tour]
(http://www.dartlang.org/docs/dart-up-and-running/contents/ch03.html).

The equality operator.

The default behavior for all [Object]s is to return true if and
only if [:this:] and [other] are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on
a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation.
That is, it must be:

 * Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw
   or return `null`.

 * Reflexive: For all objects `o`, `o == o` must be true.

 * Symmetric: For all objects `o1` and `o2`, `o1 == o2` and `o2 == o1` must
   either both be true, or both be false.

 * Transitive: For all objects `o1`, `o2`, and `o3`, if `o1 == o2` and
   `o2 == o3` are true, then `o1 == o3` must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects
should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects
was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override
the [hashCode] method as well to maintain consistency.

children.name: toString
children.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.

children.name: noSuchMethod
children.comment:
[noSuchMethod] is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method
on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the
invocation are passed to [noSuchMethod] in an [Invocation].
If [noSuchMethod] returns a value, that value becomes the result of
the original invocation.

The default behavior of [noSuchMethod] is to throw a
[NoSuchMethodError].

children.name: hashCode
children.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the
same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality
operator [:==:]. Other than that there are no guarantees about
the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and
there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides [hashCode] it should override the
equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

children.name: runtimeType
children.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

Creates a new [Object] instance.

[Object] instances have no meaningful state, and are only useful
through their identity. An [Object] instance is equal to itself
only.

children.name: engineID
children.comment: ID of the engine receiving the event.

children.name: contextID
children.comment: ID of the context where the surrounding text will be deleted.

children.name: offset
children.comment:
The offset from the caret position where deletion will start. This value
can be negative.

children.name: length
children.comment: The number of characters to be deleted

children.name: engineID
children.comment: ID of the engine to use

children.name: items
children.comment: Array of MenuItems to update

children.name: engineID
children.comment: ID of the engine to use

children.name: items
children.comment: MenuItems to add. They will be added in the order they exist in the array.

children.name: contextID
children.comment: ID of the context that owns the candidate window.

children.name: candidateID
children.comment: ID of the candidate to select.

children.name: contextID
children.comment: ID of the context that owns the candidate window.

children.name: candidates
children.comment: List of candidates to show in the candidate window

children.name: engineID
children.comment: ID of the engine to set properties on.

children.name: contextID
children.comment: ID of the context where the text will be committed

children.name: text
children.comment: The text to commit

children.name: contextID
children.comment: ID of the context where the composition will be cleared

children.name: contextID
children.comment: ID of the context where the composition text will be set

children.name: text
children.comment: Text to set

children.name: selectionStart
children.comment: Position in the text that the selection starts at.

children.name: selectionEnd
children.comment: Position in the text that the selection ends at.

children.name: cursor
children.comment: Position in the text of the cursor.

children.name: segments
children.comment: List of segments and their associated types.

children.name: MenuItem
children.comment:
A menu item used by an input method to interact with the user from the
language menu.

children.name: id
children.comment: String that will be passed to callbacks referencing this MenuItem.

children.name: label
children.comment: Text displayed in the menu for this item.

children.name: style
children.comment:
Enum representing if this item is: check, radio, or a separator.  Radio
buttons between separators are considered grouped.
enum of `check`, `radio`, `separator`

children.name: visible
children.comment: Indicates this item is visible.

children.name: checked
children.comment: Indicates this item should be drawn with a check.

children.name: enabled
children.comment: Indicates this item is enabled.

children.name: InputContext
children.comment: Describes an input Context

children.name: contextID
children.comment:
This is used to specify targets of text field operations.  This ID becomes
invalid as soon as onBlur is called.

children.name: type
children.comment:
Type of value this text field edits, (Text, Number, Password, etc)
enum of `text`, `number`, `password`

children.name: KeyboardEvent
children.comment: See http://www.w3.org/TR/DOM-Level-3-Events/#events-KeyboardEvent

children.name: type
children.comment:
One of keyup or keydown.
enum of `keyup`, `keydown`

children.name: requestId
children.comment: The ID of the request.

children.name: key
children.comment: Value of the key being pressed

children.name: code
children.comment:
Value of the physical key being pressed. The value is not affected by
current keyboard layout or modifier state.

children.name: altKey
children.comment: Whether or not the ALT key is pressed.

children.name: ctrlKey
children.comment: Whether or not the CTRL key is pressed.

children.name: shiftKey
children.comment: Whether or not the SHIFT key is pressed.

children.name: capsLock
children.comment: Whether or not the CAPS_LOCK is enabled.

children.name: title
children.comment: The title string of details description.

children.name: body
children.comment: The body string of detail description.

children.name: visible
children.comment: True to show the Candidate window, false to hide it.

children.name: cursorVisible
children.comment: True to show the cursor, false to hide it.

children.name: vertical
children.comment:
True if the candidate window should be rendered vertical, false to make it
horizontal.

children.name: pageSize
children.comment: The number of candidates to display per page.

children.name: auxiliaryText
children.comment: Text that is shown at the bottom of the candidate window.

children.name: auxiliaryTextVisible
children.comment: True to display the auxiliary text, false to hide it.

children.name: windowPosition
children.comment:
Where to display the candidate window. If set to 'cursor', the window
follows the cursor. If set to 'composition', the window is locked to the
beginning of the composition.
enum of `cursor`, `composition`

children.name: OnSurroundingTextChangedEvent
children.comment:
Called when the editable string around caret is changed or when the caret
position is moved. The text length is limited to 100 characters for each back
and forth direction.

children.name: engineID
children.comment: ID of the engine receiving the event

children.name: surroundingInfo
children.comment: The surrounding information.

children.name: OnMenuItemActivatedEvent
children.comment: Called when the user selects a menu item

children.name: engineID
children.comment: ID of the engine receiving the event

children.name: name
children.comment: Name of the MenuItem which was activated

children.name: OnCandidateClickedEvent
children.comment: This event is sent if this extension owns the active IME.

children.name: engineID
children.comment: ID of the engine receiving the event

children.name: candidateID
children.comment: ID of the candidate that was clicked.

children.name: button
children.comment:
Which mouse buttons was clicked.
enum of `left`, `middle`, `right`

children.name: OnKeyEventEvent
children.comment: This event is sent if this extension owns the active IME.

children.name: engineID
children.comment: ID of the engine receiving the event

children.name: keyData
children.comment: Data on the key event

children.name: ChromeInputIme
children.comment:
Use the `chrome.input.ime` API to implement a custom IME for Chrome OS. This
allows your extension to handle keystrokes, set the composition, and manage
the candidate window.

children.name: setComposition
children.comment:
Set the current composition. If this extension does not own the active IME,
this fails.

children.name: clearComposition
children.comment:
Clear the current composition. If this extension does not own the active
IME, this fails.

children.name: commitText
children.comment: Commits the provided text to the current input.

children.name: setCandidateWindowProperties
children.comment:
Sets the properties of the candidate window. This fails if the extension
doesnt own the active IME

children.name: setCandidates
children.comment:
Sets the current candidate list. This fails if this extension doesnt own
the active IME

children.name: setCursorPosition
children.comment:
Set the position of the cursor in the candidate window. This is a no-op if
this extension does not own the active IME.

children.name: setMenuItems
children.comment: Adds the provided menu items to the language menu when this IME is active.

children.name: updateMenuItems
children.comment: Updates the state of the MenuItems specified

children.name: deleteSurroundingText
children.comment: Deletes the text around the caret.

children.name: keyEventHandled
children.comment:
Indicates that the key event received by onKeyEvent is handled.  This
should only be called if the onKeyEvent listener is asynchronous.

[requestId] Request id of the event that was handled.  This should come
from keyEvent.requestId

[response] True if the keystroke was handled, false if not

children.name: onActivate
children.comment:
This event is sent when an IME is activated. It signals that the IME will
be receiving onKeyPress events.

children.name: onDeactivated
children.comment:
This event is sent when an IME is deactivated. It signals that the IME will
no longer be receiving onKeyPress events.

children.name: onFocus
children.comment:
This event is sent when focus enters a text box. It is sent to all
extensions that are listening to this event, and enabled by the user.

children.name: onBlur
children.comment:
This event is sent when focus leaves a text box. It is sent to all
extensions that are listening to this event, and enabled by the user.

children.name: onInputContextUpdate
children.comment:
This event is sent when the properties of the current InputContext change,
such as the the type. It is sent to all extensions that are listening to
this event, and enabled by the user.

children.name: onKeyEvent
children.comment: This event is sent if this extension owns the active IME.

children.name: onCandidateClicked
children.comment: This event is sent if this extension owns the active IME.

children.name: onMenuItemActivated
children.comment: Called when the user selects a menu item

children.name: onSurroundingTextChanged
children.comment:
Called when the editable string around caret is changed or when the caret
position is moved. The text length is limited to 100 characters for each
back and forth direction.

children.name: onReset
children.comment: This event is sent when chrome terminates ongoing text input session.

children.name: ime
children.comment: Accessor for the `chrome.input.ime` namespace.
